3.01.text:
Ian Dejardin:– Moving onto the next project
which is from The Holburne Museum and it’s

7.80.text:
called, ‘From the Inside-Out: 18th-century
Portraits meet 21st-century Science’ and

15.08.text:
it involves a project which was looking at
research into the brain in the 21st-century.

19.29.text:
So research into the brain and looking with
that influence, on 18th-century portraits

26.69.text:
and this is being presented for us by Amina
Wright, who is the Senior Curator at the Holburne

34.82.text:
and Louise Campion, Learning and Community
Engagement Officer at the Holburne. I should

40.67.text:
say I know Amina of old because I employed
her many, many years ago at Kenwood. So over

46.34.text:
to you both.
Louise Campion:– We’re going to share

55.75.text:
the story of a creative engagement project
inspired by the Holburne’s 18th-century

61.18.text:
portrait collection. The Neuro-Portraits project
developed out of a collaboration between The

68.10.text:
Holburne Museum’s Gardener’s Lodge Art
Group, a local artist and the University of

73.61.text:
Bath’s Department of Science.
So, there are more neurons in your head than

83.51.text:
stars in the galaxy. Neurons, for anybody
that doesn’t know, are the nerve cells which

91.24.text:
transmit impulses in our brains. Sometimes
the intensity of our own inner worlds, our

100.33.text:
consciousness can feel overwhelming and lonely
rather like floating through the immense depths

106.09.text:
of space, as I think this image seems to convey.
And this was an image created from the project.

114.23.text:
However, as social animals, we strive to find
common ground. We try to find our own personal

121.12.text:
ways to connect with other people and understand
them. The sparks of recognition when we do

127.48.text:
connect - Yes, that happened to me, I know
that feeling! - help to validate our own experiences

134.48.text:
and make us feel less alone. Sometimes, if
we’re lucky, we experience these feelings

140.34.text:
when we recognise the familiar in art.
The engagement project we’re going to talk

146.29.text:
about sought to inspire such connections.
However, these connections were between an

151.45.text:
art group (the Gardener’s Lodge Art Group)
and the Holburne’s collection of 18th-century

157.54.text:
portraits, separated by 250 years and a multitude
of cultural and social differences. We’re

165.90.text:
going to share the story of an art/science
collaboration and describing how the project

170.91.text:
evolved and the outcomes and the key lessons
we learnt.

174.17.text:
So, who was involved in the project? I’ll
start by talking about the Gardener’s Lodge.

181.93.text:
The Holburne’s mission statement, as you
can see on our website, is changing lives

187.30.text:
through art. Because we know that experiencing
and being inspired by our diverse collection,

194.34.text:
art exhibitions and site can have a really
positive impact on our visitors’ health

199.33.text:
and wellbeing. However, I’m sure everyone
working in the museum sector know that there

206.81.text:
are some groups in our local communities who
are less likely to visit museums, due to a

212.52.text:
range of social, cultural and sometimes financial
barriers. We’re really fortunate at the

218.59.text:
Holburne, because we’re a free entry museum
and this, in theory, should increase accessibility

225.61.text:
for those on low incomes. However, there are
still many other reasons why people who could

232.09.text:
potentially benefit, for instance, people
who are long-term unemployed, socially isolated,

240.08.text:
who have experienced mental health issues
or long-term physical ill-health, may not

248.81.text:
come.
So for the last seven years, the Holburne

253.41.text:
has sought to actively reach out and engage
with these groups of sometimes marginalised

259.25.text:
adults in our local communities. This work
began as a partnership project with the local

265.95.text:
homeless night shelter, called Julian House.
And it came out of a recognition that the

272.79.text:
museum shared its surroundings with many rough
sleepers who congregated in Sydney Gardens,

279.62.text:
which was the Georgian pleasure gardens, is
now a public park which surrounds the Holburne.

287.13.text:
And here we have a very pixelated image of
part of that outreach project, at the night

296.46.text:
shelter and you might recognise one of the
people who definitely isn’t homeless, there,

302.95.text:
visiting the group. So, many of our participants
that have come to the group might have battled

314.17.text:
with traumatic events in their lives, mental
health issues, addiction, breakdown and also

321.12.text:
poor physical health and some have made choices
that have put them outside of society, really.

328.42.text:
But the fact that draws this diverse group
of people together is really a love of art

334.68.text:
and an openness to creativity and the benefits
this can bring in terms of wellbeing and self-confidence.

341.37.text:
So, the project. Every year the Gardener’s
Lodge Art Group works towards exhibiting in

349.15.text:
Fringe Arts Bath or FAB, a city wide celebration
of the arts which uses empty shop fronts and

356.58.text:
public spaces to showcase creativity in all
its wild and wacky forms. For instance, having

364.36.text:
somebody cellotaped to the floor for about
two hours, not moving.... And this year, the

374.33.text:
group wanted to focus, for that exhibition,
on portraiture and I’d noticed how the 18th-century

382.41.text:
portraits generated deeply-felt responses.
This is the Gardener’s Lodge Art Group.

388.95.text:
Sorry, I missed a slide. So here are some
of the things that the Gardener’s Lodge

393.01.text:
Art Group do and this is the lodge itself.
So this is where we meet and these are just

400.04.text:
some of the projects we’ve done and here
is our Picture Gallery.

406.80.text:
So I’d noticed how the 18th-century portraits
generated really deeply-felt responses in

412.74.text:
a number of participants, including Natasha,
who expressed frustration that our portrait

418.36.text:
gallery was full of the faces of predominantly
white, male, elite, 18th-century high society,

427.43.text:
many of whom enjoyed family fortunes built
on the slave trade. She felt she was unable

433.37.text:
to relate to the people and actively disliked
what they stood for and the lack of alternative

439.14.text:
voices or narratives in the gallery.
Another member of the Gardener’s Lodge Art

446.56.text:
Group talked about the skewed moral compass
which allowed wealthy families, such as the

454.44.text:
Auriol and Dashwood Families, which we’re
going to look at in a Zoffany painting in

459.13.text:
a minute, and the Holburne dynasty themselves,
that this moral compass which allowed them

468.22.text:
to show great tenderness and sensitivity to
each other in their families and yet be immune

474.64.text:
to the feelings of their servants and the
injustices of the slave trade on which much

480.61.text:
of their wealth was built on. And he talked
about circles of compassion and he wondered

487.02.text:
how, in general, people decide where their
compassion stops. And I think that’s really

493.07.text:
poignant at this moment in time, in Europe
when we’re all asking those kind of questions.

499.77.text:
As we read the mainly historical notes about
each portrait, we began to wonder, as a group,

507.22.text:
was it possible to approach the portraits
in another way which created space to imagine

512.17.text:
the sitter’s inner lives and their mental
states? As one member of the group pointed

518.05.text:
out, mental health issues are not a 21st-century
discovery. Some of these people may have experienced

525.99.text:
depression, anxiety, but society would not
have recognised these conditions and so there

531.82.text:
isn’t a trace. Walking around the galleries
with Amina, it soon became apparent that some

539.98.text:
of the Holburne’s most famous faces might
indeed have experienced periods of poor mental

545.50.text:
health and that there were potentially untold
narratives which could be the starting points

550.61.text:
for new 21st-century interpretations of our
18th-century portraits.

557.63.text:
So with these in mind, we turned to local
artist Stephen Magrath, whose own work explores

562.68.text:
the complexities of the human body and mind
with an emphasis on microbiological inscapes

571.79.text:
and neuroscience. And members of the Gardener’s
Lodge group have been really fascinated by

577.56.text:
his previous exhibition which was called ‘The
Art of the Brain’ at the FAB the year before.

584.98.text:
And here’s one of his pieces, ‘ I Don’t
Know Who You Are But I Love You’, and this

590.68.text:
relates to a real life situation where the
person on the right in red, with the smaller,

598.34.text:
slightly atrophied brain is trying to work
out who the person in green is. They know

605.96.text:
they love them but they don’t know who they
are and in this case, it’s his wife of 50

611.78.text:
years attempting to care for his Alzheimer’s.
So that’s just an example of one of Stephen’s

617.33.text:
pieces of work.
Stephen’s work with the public engagement

621.45.text:
department at the University of Bath has used
art to share ideas and raise awareness of

626.99.text:
the current cutting edge scientific research
being undertaken there by the Pharmacy and

631.83.text:
Pharmacology Department. The department’s
work on neuroscience aims to identify etiologies

639.08.text:
and improve treatment for a variety of neurological
and neuropsychiatric disorders. So they’re

646.82.text:
trying to develop drugs and also alternative
therapeutic approaches that can positively

652.51.text:
impact on the lives of people with epilepsy,
anxiety, depression, drug addiction and Alzheimer’s.

660.37.text:
So our project began with Doctor Denise Taylor
from the Pharmacology and Pharmaceutical Department

668.18.text:
sharing her department’s work on mapping
brain activity and how scientists are attempting

674.81.text:
to record neurological differences, differences
in the brain of people who were experiencing

682.06.text:
depression, dementia, stress, addiction and
other conditions.

687.46.text:
At times this, for the group was a really
painful process, I think it’s fair to say,

694.46.text:
and the parameters of the discussion really
needed to be sensitively managed. I’m just

701.04.text:
going to show you some of the images. So we
learnt about the different parts of the brain

705.99.text:
and what they control and we saw some amazing
images. Some of them are computer generated.

714.66.text:
This one shows the neural networks of the
brain and we saw a lot about how electrical

724.40.text:
activity, how the impulses in the brain can
be measured. And this image is very striking,

734.58.text:
so what they’re doing is they’re comparing
brains and looking at the different levels

742.29.text:
of electrical activity. So… Oh, sorry. So
this one, the red, yellow and the sort of

755.16.text:
warm colours, this is more electrical activity,
higher levels and where it’s blue, it’s

763.99.text:
less. So we looked at some of these images.
And again, this is computer generated but

769.47.text:
it shows the neural networks and these are
the impulses, moving from one neuron to another.

780.46.text:
So the other really interesting thing, the
good news, really, from the research that

787.83.text:
we looked at was that there is something called,
neurone plasticity which means that your brain,

796.64.text:
there is possibility, even when you’re older,
for regrowth, new pathways, adaptation. So

803.72.text:
if you have had some kind of injury or something
in your brain, you can regrow, you can learn

810.46.text:
new routes which is a really positive message.
And that, also, good nutrition and health

818.06.text:
and exercise can really have an effect on
the brain. So you do have some control. So

826.37.text:
Stephen, also with a printmaker called Kathryn
Naylor, worked with the group for about eight

831.65.text:
weeks and taking inspiration from the beauty
of these brain scans and the microscopic neural

837.99.text:
imaging as well as wider conversations about
the brain. And the group developed responses

844.41.text:
to some of the museum’s portraits, reinterpreting
the sitters from the outside in, or the inside

855.66.text:
out, attempting to get beneath the skin and
raise awareness of their possible psychological

862.28.text:
states. So now, Amina and I are going to take
you on an alternative tour of five of the

872.08.text:
Holburne’s portraits.
Amina Wright:– So this is Admiral Holburne.

879.14.text:
Lovely portrait by Reynolds and it depicts
the grandfather and father of the Holburne

885.56.text:
Museum’s founder. Sir Thomas William Holburne,
who founded the museum, owned this painting

892.36.text:
during the 19th-century. His father, Sir Francis
was the little boy in the portrait. It hung

900.12.text:
in his dining room in Bath alongside other
family portraits and seascapes. Like his grandfather,

907.14.text:
the Admiral, Sir William was a sailor. Admiral
Holburne had been a governor of the Naval

912.29.text:
Hospital at Greenwich at the end of his life
and he actually died in the Hospital. So when

917.81.text:
his grandson, Sir William died in 1874, he
left this portrait to the Hospital. The remainder

925.41.text:
of William’s collection became The Holburne
Museum. All, except this portrait. So we are

932.37.text:
really grateful to Royal Museums Greenwich
for generously lending it back to us for a

938.92.text:
short period.
I love this composition. I love the way that

942.23.text:
it combines elements of Reynolds’s great
military and maritime, naval portraits of

951.80.text:
the 1750s with some of his most tender family
pictures. So you have the image of a powerful

957.81.text:
naval commander, who is also a daddy. He’s
also a loving protector of his child and by

964.22.text:
implication, a loving protector of his men
and of his country. Admiral Francis Holburne

971.39.text:
was nearly 50 years old when his son, the
future Sir Francis Holburne, was born. He’d

978.27.text:
had a long career at sea and then he retired
to shore duties with his new wife, a very

985.31.text:
wealthy widow called Frances Lascelles, whom
he met in Barbados. You can guess what’s

991.54.text:
coming next, can’t you? Like his wife, Admiral
Holburne had considerable interests in Barbados.

999.15.text:
He spent a lot of time in the West Indies,
as a sailor and ran a plantation near Bridgetown.

1005.39.text:
So the marriage between Holburne and Mrs Lascelles
combined two fortunes which had been built

1010.89.text:
in Barbados.
Louise Campion:– So I just want to read

1019.54.text:
to you one of the participant’s who was
involved in creating their own reinterpretation

1027.78.text:
of this portrait. She says, “I was drawn
to my chosen portrait because the little boy

1034.12.text:
just looked like he did not want to be there.
His father has wanted his son in the painting.

1040.23.text:
He loves him but he hasn’t spent a lot of
time with him. Look at how the boy is looking

1045.40.text:
out to sea. His mind’s on other things.
He doesn’t want to be there. He’s bored.

1050.45.text:
I think he’ll suffer from depression when
he’s older.” This is the reinterpretation.

1057.83.text:
I call it, ‘Blue Boy’, ‘The Admiral’s
son’. Here, Natasha has superimposed the

1068.95.text:
neural pathways of a brain scan onto the face,
using blue to denote depression as we saw

1077.02.text:
in that brain scan. It’s as though the boy
were looking out through a mental state which

1083.37.text:
is slowly taking him over and in conversation,
Natasha suggested to me how the innocence

1090.94.text:
of the boy would be corrupted by his family’s
connection with slavery, really, in the end.

1097.56.text:
After this, Natasha was hooked and continued
to research the painting in her own time and

1107.15.text:
she then… She previously questioned where
The Holburne Museum, where William Holburne’s,

1114.90.text:
who was the grandson of the Admiral, where
the family money had come from for him to

1120.45.text:
buy all the things that are now in the Holburne.
And she had a gut feeling it was from the

1126.69.text:
transatlantic slave trade and her research
led her to Barbados. And she decided to create

1133.80.text:
a portrait that literally, as we can see,
got under the skin of Admiral Holburne and

1140.19.text:
she included a mixture of symbols that reflected
the Barbados part of his life, as you can

1146.58.text:
see. She says, “I feel it depicts him as
a man who exerted extreme power and control

1152.57.text:
over people and places, in order to make money
which would undoubtedly enable him to secure

1158.06.text:
his livelihood. This enormous wealth meant
that a legacy was passed down through the

1162.79.text:
generations so that they could have great
spending power and stay in control of their

1170.27.text:
futures.” So our next portrait…
Amina Wright:– The next portrait is Her

1180.13.text:
Majesty’s, Queen Charlotte. It’s a mid-1760s
portrait attributed to Zoffany when the museum

1187.63.text:
acquired it in 1955. We now think it must
be a studio copy after a lost original by

1194.96.text:
Zoffany. So this is Queen Charlotte, Sophia
Charlotte, the daughter of the Duke of Mecklenburg-Strelitz.

1203.17.text:
She married King George, who we met this morning,
as a young man, in 1761. At the time of this

1211.97.text:
portrait, she was still only 21 or 22 but
already the mother of three or four children.

1217.65.text:
Two of whom of course, were future kings.
She and King George were very happily married

1224.40.text:
and admired by some people as a model couple.
She would go on to have another 11 children,

1231.75.text:
finishing up with Princess Amelia in 1783,
nine months before her 40th birthday.

1239.50.text:
Five years after the birth of Princess Amelia,
towards the end of 1788, her world was turned

1245.97.text:
upside down when her husband fell ill. The
King’s mental collapse completely altered

1252.18.text:
his behaviour towards her. He became hostile
and suffered violent delusions as well as

1258.49.text:
all those strange physical symptoms. At the
same time, Charlotte’s son, the Prince of

1264.81.text:
Wales, was using his father’s illness as
an opportunity to try and seize political

1269.16.text:
power and these events took a very heavy toll
on the Queen’s own mental health. She never

1276.15.text:
really fully recovered her peace of mind,
their marriage suffered. In effect, her husband’s

1282.18.text:
illness took him away from her as well as
damaging her relationship with her children.

1290.95.text:
Louise Campion:– So from this, Louise was
interested in the number of children Queen

1301.11.text:
Charlotte had had whilst still so young here.
This is her interpretation. So she explored

1311.59.text:
post-natal depression through this abstract
piece which references the FMRI brain scan

1318.35.text:
image which, again, we saw earlier, where
we see the darkened brain to show this kind

1326.56.text:
of depressed state. And to me, these delicate
red dendrites, which float beneath it are

1335.26.text:
somehow reminiscent of all the finery, the
lace and of her sleeve hanging down. So that’s

1348.53.text:
Now, we come to the Zoffany conversation piece
that Louise mentioned before. This is another

1354.98.text:
long term loan. We are so lucky that people
just lend us amazing things. It’s a wonderful

1361.06.text:
record of Zoffany’s work in Bengal in the
1780s. An informal conversation piece of the

1367.67.text:
Auriol family with their friends and servants
and it really gives us a fascinating glimpse

1373.67.text:
into this early colonial life in India.
The tea party is probably set in the garden

1380.14.text:
of James Peter Auriol. He’s the one in green
here. He was Secretary of the governing council

1387.59.text:
of Bengal, one of five children of a Huguenot
merchant from Hampstead and here are all the

1393.44.text:
five children. They all travelled to Calcutta
during the 1770s and 80s to seek their fortunes.

1401.38.text:
The brothers in the East India Company and
the sisters, in rich husbands and both sisters

1407.48.text:
married in 1782. Here they are with their
husbands. So the sister in pink is Sophia,

1416.84.text:
who was married to this gentlemen, John Prinsep
who established the indigo and cotton printing

1423.03.text:
industries in Bengal and became immensely
rich, and then in green, Charlotte, who married

1432.08.text:
Mr Dashwood here, Thomas Dashwood who was
in charge of stationary supplies for the East

1437.55.text:
India Company. Perhaps, rather a boring sounding
job but again, one that was very lucrative.

1444.05.text:
The names of the seven brothers and sisters
have been added to the lower edge of the portrait.

1449.03.text:
You might just be able to make them out but
there are actually five other people here,

1454.81.text:
none of them named, of course but all of them,
very clearly depicted. Delineated in great

1464.07.text:
detail. We know exactly what their roles were
within the household from the way that they’re

1470.69.text:
dressed. We know which caste they came from.
We know their social and religious background

1478.69.text:
and this is a really interesting document
of how the British actually built upon the

1483.69.text:
existing caste system which was quite fluid,
to actually reinforce people into their social

1491.18.text:
positions, according to their status in the
household.

1495.67.text:
Louise Campion:– So Cliff, another participant,
was drawn not to the supposed focus of this

1506.75.text:
ensemble piece which is obviously the European
ladies and gentlemen but to the servant here,

1515.52.text:
leaning to pour tea in the centre of the painting.
Here he is. And this is Cliff’s piece. By

1525.67.text:
deciding to create this individual portrait
of the anonymous servant, he’s elevated

1533.16.text:
his status. He’s used the green/blue tones
of the brain scans to create an aura around

1537.85.text:
the head. And he describes the man as having
his thoughts hijacked by his masters. He wrote,

1545.44.text:
“this is somebody who’s been snatched
out of their own life and then put into someone

1549.96.text:
else’s, to serve them. He’s there but
not there. No-one else notices him but the

1555.69.text:
artist did and Zoffany put him in the centre
of the picture.”

1563.41.text:
Amina Wright:– Another politician from the
1760s, with famous calves. Art historically,

1578.59.text:
this is a really important painting. Again,
it’s on loan. It doesn’t belong to the

1582.19.text:
museum but we’re very proud to have it because
it’s one of Gainsborough’s first, big,

1590.51.text:
life-size, full-length commissions made in
Bath. From no less a personage than the Member

1597.74.text:
of Parliament for Bristol. It was the first
work that Gainsborough ever submitted to the

1602.85.text:
Society of Artists exhibition. He sent it
from Bath, actually, to the Society’s second

1608.67.text:
exhibition in 1761 where it was catalogued
as number 34, ‘Whole Length of a Gentleman.’

1617.90.text:
People love this portrait because it’s subject
is obviously such a character. I’ll just

1624.00.text:
give you a close up of his face, there. The
very informal pose and direct gaze give a

1629.54.text:
real sense of immediacy, of a big man with
a big personality, filling a small space.

1637.06.text:
This is Robert Craggs, who had been MP for
Bristol since 1754 and we have lots of contemporary

1645.74.text:
descriptions of him. The poet, Richard Glover,
for instance, described him as a jovial and

1650.73.text:
voluptuous Irishman. He was famous for his
big voice, unflagging energy and powerful

1659.04.text:
physique. Lord Chesterfield wrote him a letter
in which he described his athletic calves,

1666.78.text:
which is such a feature of this portrait.
He’s a great example of somebody from quite

1671.62.text:
a modest background who rose rapidly through
British society. His parents were Irish, Catholic

1678.33.text:
gentry but by the time he died, he was an
Earl, with £200,000. He was actually pretty

1685.49.text:
unscrupulous in his ambitions. He was married
three times, always to rich widows and he

1691.92.text:
used his wives’ wealth for his own political
advancement. Having said that, he was heavily

1699.10.text:
criticised for his malice, his callousness
in his personal life but as a politician,

1706.04.text:
if you look at his parliamentary record, he
could also be quite compassionate. He supported

1711.97.text:
some important humanitarian causes, particularly
in Ireland. He was very loyal to Ireland,

1718.20.text:
even if he let his family down.
Louise Campionm:– So next, responding to

1729.16.text:
this, we have John’s portrait here which
I think conveys the energy of a man, a politician

1736.51.text:
firing on all cylinders. Maybe George Osborne.
The electrical impulses on the top of the

1743.98.text:
brain suggest intense neural activity and
John wrote, “he has a defined expression,

1750.74.text:
a politician’s face. I think he’s a devious
chap. I wanted to go beyond the surface, beyond

1757.81.text:
the surface impression to show his brain working.”
Amina Wright:– Now, this one isn’t really

1770.84.text:
a portrait. It’s what the artist and his
contemporaries would have known as a ‘fancy

1776.44.text:
picture’. So it’s a fantasy figure painted
for purely commercial purposes. In fact, at

1782.39.text:
least seven other versions of this subject
are known. Morland made a whole series of

1788.80.text:
these very French-style figures. Often with
the print market in mind. So house maids,

1796.16.text:
shop girls, ballad singers, all of them very
pretty but not necessarily very true to life.

1804.55.text:
So this one is called, ‘A Lady’s Maid
Soaping Linen’. She is not a laundry maid.

1809.26.text:
